Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. No
substantial violations were found.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616)204-6992.
Sincerely,
Holly K. Austin, Licensing Consultant
enclosure

INVESTIGATION:
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12405-1 Change of Placement.
Section (1) An agency shall make every reasonable effort to maintain a
Description stable placement for each child placed in foster care. The efforts
shall be documented in the child’s record.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation There is concern for the manner in which facility is managing a foster
care youth's placement.
Investigation Relative A, who is also the complainant, filed a written complaint
alleging that he has concerns with Relatives B & C, with whom Youth A
is placed. His concerns include isolating Youth A from his family and
siblings, being recovering addicts with the potential of relapse, and
having a son who is mistreating Youth A and making statements that he
does not want Youth A living there. Additionally, Relative A alleged that
4

the foster care agency workers have ignored his concerns and are not
placing with him due to the fact that he identifies as LGBTQ.
INTERVIEWS:
Complainant/Relative A - On 1/13/2023 a voicemail message was left
for Relative A. Follow-up emails were sent on 1/18/2023 and 1/25/2023.
Relative A responded on 1/25/2023 and was interviewed by phone on
1/26/2023. Relative A reported when Youth A was initially placed in
foster care, he was already living with Relative A’s father and sister.
Youth A remained in that home placed in the care of Relative A’s sister
and brother-in-law, Relatives E & F. Relative A reported that he
supported that placement, and everything was going well until Youth A
was removed from that home in July of 2021. Youth A was then placed
with Relative A’s brother and sister-in-law, Relatives B & C. Relative A
stated that he was in support of that placement at the time. He reported
that he felt he should also be studied for placement as a back-up plan
and told this to Relatives B & C, but they would not tell him what
agency they were working with, so he didn’t know who to contact. He
reported that his relationship with Relatives B & C has since
deteriorated. He reported that he sent an email to an MDHHS worker
approximately a year ago expressing concerns with Relatives B & C
after which he was contacted by a worker from Catholic Charities. He
stated that the worker discussed his concerns with him and also asked
him if he was interested in being studied for placement. Relative A
stated that he expressed interest after which he was studied and
approved for placement; however, he reported that he was told there
was no reason to move Youth A from his current placement. He
reported that he has applied to adopt Youth A as a competing party and
is awaiting a decision from the Michigan Children’s Institute.
Relative A reported that one of Youth A’s siblings, Sibling 1 lives with
Relative A. He stated that Sibling 1 doesn’t get to visit with Youth A as
much as he used to but did visit him on New Year's. He reported that
Youth A also has another sibling, Sibling 2, who is living with Relative
A’s dad and does visit with Youth A. Relative A stated that there is a
third sibling who lives with that sibling’s mother and does visit with
Youth A. Relative A stated that he feels Relatives B & C are isolating
Youth A from his family because they limit his visits with Sibling 1 and
have told Relative A that Youth A doesn’t want to visit with him, which
Relative A believes Relatives B & C told him to say.
In regard to mistreating of Youth A by Relative B & C’s biological son,
Relative A reported that, approximately a year ago, he heard Relative B
& C’s biological son say something to Youth A about wishing Youth A
4

had his own mom and dad. Relative A did address this with Relative B
who in turn punished her son, which Relative A didn’t think was
appropriate as it was a teaching moment. Relative A did raise this
concern approximately a year ago and agency staff spoke to him, but
he does not know if it was addressed with Relatives B & C by the
agency. He stated that he does not know if Relative B & C’s son still
mistreats Youth A.
Relative A stated that he doesn’t feel the agency workers take concerns
he brings to them seriously and minimize and disregard what he says
due to him identifying as LGBTQ. This feeling is due to the worker who
came to his home providing him with paperwork that said the agency
will not place children in LGBTQ homes. He stated that the worker
emphasized that he read that specific document.
Program Manager 1 - On 1/19/2023 Program Manager 1 (PM1) was
interviewed in person at the agency. PM1 reported that Youth A was
already placed with Relatives E & F when the agency accepted case
responsibility. Failure to report domestic violence concerns arose with
Relatives E & F as well as concerns with the family not following a
safety plan regarding marijuana storage in the home, resulting in a
need for a placement change. Relatives B & C expressed interest in
placement of Youth A and were subsequently studied and approved for
placement. At that time, Relative A was living with Youth A’s mother
and had a good relationship with Relatives B & C and supported the
placement. Relative B does have substance abuse history; however, he
participated in treatment and the agency has had no concerns with his
recovery. Due to Relative B’s recovery, he and Relative C have limited
contact with family members they have determined to be unhealthy for
them. PM1 reported that there have been several meetings with
Relatives B & C and the assigned agency foster care staff and
supervision to discuss their relationship with other family members and
to encourage them to maintain contact between Youth A and his
relatives. PM1 reported that Relatives B & C continue to facilitate visits
between Youth A and his half-siblings.
Program Manager 2 - On 1/19/2023 Program Manager 2 (PM2) was
interviewed in person at the agency. PM2 reported that, at the time
Youth A was placed with Relatives B & C, Relative A had a positive and
communicative relationship with Relatives B & C and no concerns were
presented by Relative A. Since that time, there has been a breakdown
in family relationships and Relative A now has a contentious
relationship with Relatives B & C. She reported that Relative A was
assessed for placement of Youth A when Relative A requested to be
4

considered for adoption after Youth A’s parents’ rights were terminated.
Relative A was approved for placement, but there was no reason to
move Youth A from the relatives with whom he was already placed.
Adoption Worker - On 1/19/2023 Adoption Worker (AW) was
interviewed in person at the agency. AW reported that she has
participated in several meeting with Relatives B & C about their
relationship with family members. Relative C does not want contact with
Youth A’s grandmother due to the chaotic and unhealthy nature of their
relationship but has maintained contact with Youth A’s half-siblings. AW
reported that Youth A was also having visits with Relative A until last
summer, when Youth A began stating he did not want to visit with
Relative A. AW spoke to Youth A about his not wanting to visit and
Youth A replied that he likes Relative A, but he would rather just stay
home with Relatives B & C than participate in visits.
AW reported that she completed an assessment of Relative A after he
requested to be considered for the placement and adoption of Youth A
in February of 2022. She reported that Relative A was approved for
placement, but he was not recommended for adoption of Youth A due
to Youth A’s time placed with Relative’s B & C and Youth A’s expressed
desire to be adopted by them. On February 25, 2022, AW told Relative
A that she was not recommending him for the adoption of Youth A and
gave him information about how he could proceed with the competing
party adoption. She reported that Relative A was thankful for providing
him the information and she hasn’t heard from him since.
AW reported that she interviewed Relative B & C’s child, Youth A’s
cousin, without his parents present about having Youth A in the home
in either July or August of 2022. Youth A’s cousin told AW that he
wants Youth A in the home and wants his parents to adopt Youth A.
Foster Care Worker - On 1/19/2023 Foster Care Worker (FCW) was
interviewed in person at the agency. FCW reported that in February of
2022 she began supervising monthly 1-hour visits between Youth A
and Relative A. She reported that in June of 2022, Relative A brought
presents for Youth A’s birthday. One of the presents was a necklace
with Youth A’s birth father’s picture and date of death which included a
note from Youth A’s mother. After that visit, FCW had a conversation
with Relative A about the inappropriateness of the gift and told him that
all items brought for Youth A would now have to be approved by the
agency before giving them to Youth A. After that visit, FCW has
continued to ask Youth A about scheduling a visit with Relative A every
4

month, but Youth A has consistently said he does not want to visit with
Relative A, stating he would rather stay home with Relatives B & C.
FCW reported that she has never observed any concerns with the
interactions between Youth A and his cousin. She reported that she has
observed them playing on several occasions and the only negative
interactions she has witnessed are age-appropriate sibling rivalry type
of interactions.
Foster Care Supervisor - On 1/19/2023 Foster Care Supervisor (FCS)
was interviewed in person at the agency. FCS reported that there have
been ongoing concerns that Youth A’s mother is living with Relative A,
despite Relative A claiming that she is no longer living with him. FCS
reported that Youth A’s siblings are not in foster care, and one is placed
with his biological mother and the others with their biological fathers,
none of which are shared by Youth A. She stated that Sibling 1, who
was placed in the care of his birth father, is actually living with Relative
A. She stated that Youth A was able to visit with Sibling 1 during the
supervised visits between Youth A and Relative A. She stated that
Relative’s B & C also arrange for all of Youth A’s siblings to come to
their house for visits with Youth A
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
All of the following documents were reviewed in MiSACWIS:
• Youth A’s Placement History:
6/24/2020 to 7/16/2021 – Relatives E & F
7/16/2021 to current – Relatives B & C
• Sibling Placement History:
Sibling 1 – 6/25/2020 parental home
Sibling 2 – 6/25/2020 parental home
Both siblings were discharged to the care of their respective
parents on 10/16/2020
• Legal History:
6/24/2020 – 12/22/2021 Temporary Court Ward
12/22/2021 – State Ward
• Social Work Contacts:
1/25/22 – email from Relative A to a DHHS Worker reporting the
same concerns as in this complaint and indicating Youth A’s
mother is no longer living with him, so Youth A should be
removed from Relatives B & C and placed with him
• 1/31/22 Safety Plan signed by FCW, FCS and Relatives B & C
addressing the concerns Relative A expressed about the
relationship between Youth A and his cousin and included steps
4

to engage the youth in therapy to establish coping skills related
to Youth A being placed in the home
• Relative A’s Relative Placement Safety Screen (MDHHS 5770)
2/4/2022 – Denied due to needed additional information
• Relative Placement Home Study (DHS 3130a)
3/10/2022 – Approved for placement of Youth A
• Intent to Adopt
3/2/2022 signed by Relative A
• Initial Foster/Adoption Home Evaluation (CWL 3130)
8/17/2022 – Denied for adoption based on Youth A’s placement
with Relatives B & C since 7/16/2021 and Youth A’s expressed
wishes to be adopted by them
Analysis The agency staff have made every reasonable effort to maintain a
stable placement for Youth A. They assessed Relative A for the
placement and adoption of Youth A after Relative A reported that Youth
A’s mother was no longer living with him. At that time, Youth A had
been in a stable relative placement for 6 months and there was no
reason to move him. The agency staff have addressed Relative A’s
concerns with Youth A’s placement and do not have concerns about
Youth A’s cousin abusing him or the potential for Relative B to relapse.
Additionally, Youth A does have visits with his siblings in his current
placement.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
February 1, 2023
_____________________________________
Holly K. Austin Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
February 1, 2023
